A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as any other; some of the questions will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada for 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer diet
- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer churches
- Pioneer recreation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Folklore in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Very few. Most of us were young (completing) and many ambitious to become successful farmers or stock raisers. Most who moved went to farms formerly owned by relatives.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

Very few moved. Many town & city dwellers were satisfied by the soil, its settle on our ancient range thus curtailing our means of expanding. Very few of these city new comers stayed but returned to the cities as soon as possible. A few (very few) remained and became town site farmers.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I was a rural school trustee until the formation of our school trust No. 64 in 1945, when I was elected to the new trust Board of Trustee for said trust representing that said trust continuously until our leaving said in 1954. During the latter period I was required to act as "helper" to any young teacher unable through disciplinary or curricular difficulties to make satisfactory progress. By now our son was able to manage our land.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

We did not consider ourselves to be numbered among the "first," but I grew to know hundreds of settlers not of Canadian origin, through good opportunities such as Census taking, Returning Officer on Federal, Provincial and Municipal levels and other matters. This opened a working knowledge of several languages which proved invaluable.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Pullinger, named by a resident whose ancestors hailed from county of West Meath Ireland. Pallet Lake, when tradition says that the first settlers then inhabited on Pallets for food and lake water for drink. Day Lake—(really a wonder district)—named romantically by a family from Gloucester England. Post Office named to honor the name of the village they served. Most rural schools have not been abandoned since the advent of Consolidation or Consolidated schools—a distinct advantage for the ambitious pupil, but bitterly resented by early residents who since this inception have recognized the advantages for their children and become champions of the change ours.
